Apple Computer Inc. plans to announce on Monday that it will begin marketing software for Macintosh and Windows-based computers delivered on a CD-ROM disk.
The new system will allow personal computer users to try demonstration programs on their systems, then call an 800 number and receive a numeric unlocking key upon purchase of the application.
The new service, called Software Dispatch, will be available in November for Macintosh users and early next year for Windows systems.

One of the issues in the new system of software distribution involves developing ways to distribute documentation along with the software. Apple is using a system it developed internally called Docviewer on the Macintosh version and Adobe Systems' Acrobat Reader technology for the Windows CD-ROM. This permits computer users to view documentation on the screen or print it out.

After sputtering for years, CD-ROM systems have become more popular among computer users recently. They are preferred to floppy disks for software distribution by some publishers because they lower manufacturing costs.
